channel.title: BBC News - World

item.title: Kabul airport attack: 'Today I saw doomsday'
item.description: Afghans caught up in the twin blasts outside Kabul airport speak of the horror they witnessed.

item.title: Afghanistan: US will hunt down Kabul airport attack jihadists, says Biden
item.description: US President adds the Kabul airlift will go on, after bombings killed 90, including 13 US troops.

item.title: Covid: Vaccine complications dwarfed by virus risks
item.description: Researchers says despite stroke and clotting risks, Covid vaccines have substantial benefits.

item.title: Afghanistan: Pen Farthing team 'turned away' from airport
item.description: Defence Secretary Ben Wallace says supporters of an animal charity have "taken up too much time".

item.title: Nigeria: Gunmen free kidnapped schoolchildren
item.description: The community paid a ransom and even bought motorbikes for the kidnappers, the head teacher says.

item.title: Austrian ex-far-right leader Strache guilty of corruption
item.description: The verdict comes two years after a video sting ended Heinz-Christian Strache's political career.

item.title: Covid vaccine: More than half of Indian adults have had first jab
item.description: Some 473 million adults have received at least one dose of a coronavirus vaccine so far.

item.title: Jo Ferrari: Wanted Thai police chief surrenders after manhunt
item.description: The former officer, accused of torturing a suspect to death, spoke at an unusual press conference.

item.title: Apple chief executive Tim Cook gets $750m payout
item.description: The award of more than five million Apple shares comes as Mr Cook marks a decade as the firm's boss.

item.title: Israel's Bennett seeks reset with US at first meeting with Biden
item.description: Israeli PM hopes Joe Biden will agree to help stop Iran's nuclear programme at their first meeting.

item.title: Daniel Dias: History's greatest para-swimmer
item.description: Daniel Dias has won more than 25 medals for Brazil over the past four Paralympic Games but will be retiring after Tokyo.

item.title: French presidency: Michel Barnier joins race 'to change France'
item.description: The former EU Brexit negotiator says he will take on Emmanuel Macron in the elections next spring.

item.title: Afghanistan airport attack: Who are IS-K?
item.description: The jihadist group - set up in 2015 - is blamed for some of the worst atrocities in recent years.

item.title: Afghans in Calais prepare to risk lives again to reach UK
item.description: Aid agencies on the French coast are preparing for a new influx of migrants trying to get to the UK.

item.title: Afghanistan's Uyghurs fear the Taliban, and now China too
item.description: Members of the ethnic group say they fear the Taliban takeover could bring China to their doorstep.

item.title: The hard men removing squatters in Spain
item.description: Some squatters in Spain demand cash before leaving - so eviction firms have arisen to handle the talks.

item.title: Indian-American gay couples find new forms of union amid stigma
item.description: Although gay marriage is legal in the US, Indian-American couples struggle to find priests to marry them.

item.title: Africa's week in pictures: 20-26 August 2021
item.description: A selection of the best photos from the African continent and beyond.

item.title: Kabul airport bomb attacks leave many casualties
item.description: Reports say at least 90 people were killed, with civilians and US military personnel among the dead.

item.title: Afghanistan airlift rescue: Thousands of refugees arrive at US airbase in Germany
item.description: Thousands of people are being evacuated from Kabul airport to the Ramstein Air Base in Germany.

item.title: The Red Cross in Afghanistan: 'If we leave, who stays?'
item.description: Dr Alberto Cairo, who has worked in Afghanistan since 1990, tells the BBC "if we leave who stays?".

item.title: Afghanistan: Former Royal Marine on the chaos at Kabul airport
item.description: A former Royal Marine, who was near to the explosions at Kabul airport, describes being caught in the chaos.

item.title: Afghanistan: 'The pain of watching my country burn from afar'
item.description: Hundreds of Afghan have taken refuge in India but they are worried about their families back home.

item.title: What we know so far about Kabul airport attack
item.description: The bombings came hours after warnings to citizens to stay away from the airport, due to an imminent threat.

item.title: Young Afghan mayor who fled Taliban hidden in car
item.description: One of Afghanistan's first female mayors, Zarifa Ghafari, describes her dramatic escape to Germany.

item.title: Afghanistan's economy in crisis after Taliban take-over
item.description: Even before the Taliban gained control, Afghanistan's economy was fragile.

item.title: Afghanistan: The 'undefeated' Panjshir Valley - an hour from Kabul
item.description: The Panjshir Valley has been a flashpoint in Afghanistan's turbulent history - now it's happening again.

item.title: Tears on the tarmac as Afghan journalist speaks to BBC
item.description: Wahida Faizi says she cannot stay in Afghanistan because she believes the Taliban will kill her.

item.title: Bilal Sarwary: 'The plane hit the tower and all our lives changed'
item.description: Afghan journalist Bilal Sarwary was selling carpets when 9/11 happened. From that day on, everything changed.
